replies.author: @Mayhzon
replies.text:
‚ÄãDavid Yeakle 
Well did you learn from it?

America's about to go down in flames. The writing is on the wall, the "activists" are out and about and the ship has set sail for fail.

Clearly important lessons weren't learned. The lessons the Weimar Republic teaches, that is. You're living in a modernized replica of it and chances are you have noticed but are unable to stop it.

Polarization of the nation, leftwing and rightwing squads patrolling the streets and causing harm, impoverished working class with constantly worsening conditions, over-privileged ruling and corporate class, high crime rate, sexual degeneracy everywhere, nothing is sacred anymore - Not even children - And finally the whole thing comes crumbling down. All that's missing is the economic spark of depression to ignite the powder keg. And almost as if it was strategically called in, here comes the awfully convenient covid lockdowns, which have surely kneecapped any GDP momentum you initially had. Millions have lost their jobs over nothing.

The political actors are dropping their facade of a fair debate-based fighting stage and go for low-blow after low-blow:
Emergency laws and executive orders executed by the president, because he otherwise can't even get any legislative changes done. A largely *hostile* parliament that constantly defies its own mission statement just to block the legislative process from happening. Smear campaign after smear campaign making the news indoctrinating the masses with lies and slander for or against one side.
Talks of a "revolution" everywhere, yet everyone talking about it somehow expects to magically go through the whole process unscathed, clearly thinking everyone else will pay the toll.

In one sentence: Delusion rules the day and destruction the night.

All of this and much more would describe the Weimar Republic to a T,  which quickly was descending the downwards spiral from the mid 20's onward. Yet these words are also valid for the USA now. The result from decades worth of sabotage and a weak democracy that just took the pounding year after year without fighting back against the *OBVIOUS* aggressors.

So how 'bout that history of yours? Seems many a person didn't learn from it. Go tell those college students and activists about the Weimar Republic and how it came to fall. Because, spoilers, no matter who "wins" the fighting in the end - It's going to end badly for most of you. I don't think you will be able to change their mind, though.
Yuri Bezmenov said it best: "Once the demoralization is complete - Even if you showed them that White is White and Black is Black, they'd still not believe it."

Wie oft bist du schon auf Menschen getroffen, welche ohne jegliche Grundlage Vermutungen √ºber dich als Person, √ºber deine Sichtweisen, √ºber dein Leben angestellt haben? - Sowas ist das Ergebnis, wenn man das Internet f√ºr voll nimmt. Und genau diese langsam voranschreitende Entwicklung, stimmt mich verflucht traurig & l√§sst mich v√∂llig Hoffnungslos zur√ºck. :/

replies.author: @pianoraves
replies.text:
@are_you_f_serious also zusammengefasst lauten meine Gedanken bez√ºglich der Frage, ob man dem Internet v√∂llig freie Hand gew√§hren sollte, die Faust des einen muss da stoppen wo die Nase des anderen Beginnt. Meinungs- und Satirefreiheit sind wichtig und richtig, aber Moderation muss dort walten wo Schadenspotential entsteht; besonders, wo Hass gesch√ºrt wird, der darauf abzielt, Menschenrechte zu verletzen. Echokammern die soetwas erm√∂glichen m√ºssen aufgebrochen werden. Das kann man als Individuum nur insofern tun, dass man in denjenigen Diskussionen, die au√üerhalb oder am Rand der eigenen Blase stattfinden, dem von mir oben beschriebenen Prinzip zu folgen. 

Soll nicht heissen dass ich meine dass im Internet kein Platz f√ºr kontroverse Meinungen sein sollte, oder gar f√ºr Meinungen und Pers√∂nlichkeiten, die nicht dem aktuellen kulturellen Mainstream entsprechen, sondern dass diese durch Moderation davon abgehalten werden sollten, zu extrem zu werden und zu reale Gewalt zu katalysieren. Ich glaube, Menschen sind dazu in der Lage eine Ordnung die eine solche Balance gew√§hrleistet aufzubauen und aufrechtzuerhalten, aber wenn sie das nicht tun, und anderen Sichtweisen nicht mit Vernunft begegnen, dazu tendieren m√∂gen, der st√§rkeren, der lauteren, der Stimme die die Welt in zu einfache Begriffe herunterbrechen will und die anderen Menschen schaden m√∂chte, das Feld zu √ºberlassen oder ihr hinterherzurennen.

@pianoraves Das scheint mir ziemlich Idealisiert zu sein, so wie auch direkt ins Extreme abzudriften. - Nat√ºrlich sollten tats√§chliche Verst√∂√üe gegen die Menschenrechte geahndet & bek√§mpft werden wie zb. solche Politischen T√∂tungslisten auf Telegram oder Menschenverachtende Statements gegen einzelne Ethnien etc. Doch leider erleben wir aktuell bereits, dass dies in vielen F√§llen von fragilen Individuen missbraucht wird indem sie Kritik an ihnen selbst, Humor √ºber Sie oder das Sie von Menschen einfach nicht gemocht werden als "Hass sch√ºren" darstellen, einzig & allein um es als Vorwand benutzen zu k√∂nnen, ihnen unliebsames loszuwerden. - Wie viele Politiker, Influencer, Firmen oder Promis sprechen sofort von "Hass" gegen Sie als Person/Institution obwohl der Gro√üteil dessen was ihnen widerf√§hrt nichts anderes als unliebsame Kritik an ihrem tun bzw. ihrer Person ist? - Oftmals wird ehrliche & direkte Kritik sofort als Hass deklariert um seine Kritiker zu diskreditieren. - Denn leider Gottes, funktioniert es nunmal. - Es hei√üt "Die verbreiten Hass, die sind die B√∂sen! - Konzentriert euch nicht auf den Inhalt den sie √§u√üern, sondern darauf das Sie mich hassen, denn ich bin das Opfer!" 

Dabei ist Hass, dass was ich gegen√ºber Katzen empfinde. Hass ist dass, was Neonazis gegen√ºber Juden empfinden. Hass ist dass, was diese radikalen Religionsmissbrauchenden ******* gegen√ºber Andersgl√§ubigen/Atheisten empfinden. Doch dass, was in den meisten F√§llen von Personen des √ñffentlichen Lebens oder auch Anonymen Individuen als "Hass" bezeichnet wird, ist nichts anderes als pure Ehrlichkeit, nicht anderes als beleidigende Kritik Ihnen gegen√ºber. Womit sie einfach nicht umgehen k√∂nnen oder es eben nicht wollen. Ich hab es einige male schon Erlebt. Der Account hier, ist nicht ohne Grund neu. Sei bitte nicht so Ignorant, zu glauben dass das alles niemand ausnutzt. Auch jetzt schon, wird legitime Kritik als Hasssch√ºrend deklariert und dem entsprechend wird man direkt gesperrt.

Dass man sowohl unliebige Kritik an den eigenen Ideen annimmt, als auch solche die sich an die eigene Kritik an den Ideen anderer richtet, ohne Zensur zu verlangen, oder zu behaupten dass man Opfer von Zensur sei.

replies.author: @RustyDust101
replies.text:
My Granddad was a young man during the hyperinflation in Germany.¬¥in 1923. He got his weekly salary first in a small paper bag, later in large paper bag, then he had to take the shopping basket of his wife to carry home the wads of paper money, until finally he had to carry a suitcase to work to carry home his salary. It was a nice leather suitcase. One day, he set it down when he waited for the bus, and a thief stole it and ran off with it. My Granddad ran after him only to find the pile of paper money on the ground where the thief had dumped it, as the suitcase with the money was too heavy and slowed him down in running away. The thief just took the suitcase because it was worth more than all the money in it.
True story.

replies.text:
"Pride," like many words, has more than one definition and application. If you've spent your whole life with media that never shows someone like you, or who shows them in a negative light; if your culture's understanding of your ethnicity, gender, or sexuality is as a lesser being; then being able to cast off the "shame" imposed by the dominant culture and openly proclaim that what makes you different is worth valuing is the kind of "pride" we're talking about. 

Trying to force-fit a "pride" into only one myopic definition is on par with people who reject evolution because "it's just a theory."

Not to mention how they weren't blacks since there's many genetic differences between blacks and basically any other racial group that would make that more than impossible such as blacks being mixed with humanoid species (forgot its name) that neither whites or Asians have in their blood, plus the fact that the only blacks who have neanderthal blood had non black ancestors so the myth of humans coming from Africa and all of them being black is old and can be disproven in many ways

replies.author: @FruitingPlanet
replies.text:
@Freakazoidmaxxing Not everything you read on the Internet is true, unless it comes from a peer reviewed paper. 
The first thing is, yes there were other humanoids find in Europe, that lived here a few million years ago, but these were not much more human than a chimpanzee is today and the have no direct lineage, meaning they probably went extinct again with changing climate. 
Second the color of their skin is totally irrelevant to ones skeleton and the genetic differences within African populations are usually greater then when comparing one african population and one european population. 
The neanderthaler seemed to have lived in large parts of eurasia and have also interbreed with us in those areas, as there were no neanderthalers in Africa, everyone with neanderthaler DNA in Africa has ancestors from europe or asia. 
Anyways when pretty well when the modern humans left Africa, there were four major events either through Egypt or the horn of Africa, we can even test exactly which way and what period our mothers line came from, because we only inherit mitochondria from our mother and can trace mitochondrial mutations precisely, as someone who studied biology, I even did that myself (doing the experiments). 
Third it is possible that some very early primates settled in Africa from Asia or Europe but from what we know that's unlikely, the likely chronology is, that humans developed in the African savanna, evolved and settled all over Africa, some left Africa very early and developed into other species like the neanderthaler, then the modern human left Africa roughly some 200-300 thousand years ago and spreads everywhere, a few also coming back ofc.
Btw. One interesting fact you might not know, from DNA evidence in mummies found in swamps or ice, we know for certain that all humans at least until 4-5 thousand bc. almost all at least until 2000 bc. were "black" /far dark skin, light skin color is a mutation that happened two times, once in Asia a bit earlier and later in Europe.

text: Being a Polish person and knowing our troubled history with our neighbours I honestly say that this video brought a tear to my eye. I understand how hard it is to live with the burden of your parents and grandparents wrongdoings. I understand how troubled history German people had. I might be one of the few Polish people who openly reach a friendly hand and send love to my German friends, but I will do it over and over again to bury the past and look for the future.

replies.author: @synshenron798
replies.text: Thats how I feel about American history. I as an American have apologized to many people for what my ancestors did to their ancestors. It hurts me greatly to know that I had ancestors who hurt so many people whether it was native americans, black folks or Asian folks. Whomever it is I feel awful. We have a brutal past and I know that what the rest of the world sees is a nation of people who are, at least at this moment in time, fracturing the nation.  I speak for all the sane, calm and collected people of my home when I say we don‚Äôt condone the actions of our ancestors. We are sickened and hurt by the bloody and violent history of our home but there are some of my generation who want to burry our history and erase it and there are many many others who disagree. I myself own a confederate flag and its not because I condone their stance, quite the opposite. I keep it as a reminder that this was one event in history that shaped my home into what it is and without it we may not be what we are today.  This song speaks to me like this, it says to me that each country has a dark side of its history like it or not. That we have all fought bloody and brutal battles. Some that were pointless and others that were very much needed. My nations history is full of ups and downs. By a lot of the world America is seen as a bully of smaller countries, bossing them around and putting rules in place for them even though they are their own country. The way we see it is we have to be that big brother figure, putting rules in place to try to keep some countries from harming others. Sadly we haven‚Äôt done much to Russia for their attacks on Ukraine though. But I want to say this, To anyone who believes my country has wronged you or those who have been hurt by us I‚Äôm sorry. I hope y‚Äôall can forgive us for our wrong doings and that we can move forward from our past mistakes. I want to say this, my countries leaders a lot of times do not represent what the average person stands for. I wish to make amends with everyone in the world and I dream of a day where we all can grow closer as allies and friends. I know it sounds cheesy or cliche, especially over a song but I mean everything I‚Äôve said. I hope one day in my lifetime that I can see more countries forgive and move forward from what our ancestors did

replies.author: @Kenghym
replies.text:
I'm in the fun position of being born in Germany to Polish parents, right after they fled their homeland, shortly before everything fell apart. As a child I would spend my summers in Komorze and Krak√≥w and the winters in Zakopane with friends and family so it's just as much part of my culture, as the things I learnd in Germany, going to school and living here.
Seeing how politics in Poland have changed over the last decade was... complicated. I have not been there in 5 years and my heart bleeds whenever I think about it. On the other hand the recent war and russia being... well, everything I have been warned of in the storys my grandparents told me... I felt the urge to go back and help. Halp in any way I can, help the people and if they would DARE to step on polish soil... I don't know, I honestly think I might just go back then. Go and protect Poland like my Grandfather did when he joined the Armia Krajowa, 80 years ago. At the same time a am insanely proud of 'my people' in Poland. I'm not even sure I'm allowed to feel that way (which is ridiculous) but I still feel a very strong connection to the history of my family and Poland and yes - am proud of it. At the same time I can be proud of german aspects of my personality without the guilt a 'germanic' German feels. My family was on the other side, we fought against the Nazis... but if I cherish being orderly and being good at execution of rigid protocols (when you work in science this is a good thing) don't I cherish something I learned from a people who went way, WAY too far and lost their humanity for a while there? Is that even a good thing then...?  
National identity and the love and/or hate one might have for their home nation is a complicated thing.

text: As a Jew I was never offended by the brief trailer for the video depicting band members about to be hung.  Because it INSTANTLY hit me as a stark condemnation- a big middle finger- to the Third Reich and all it stood for.  It never seemed like a cheap stunt to me, and I didn't understand the controversy.  Thanks for exploring the other images in the video and explaining the related history, of which I as an American know very little.

replies.author: @DinosaurVid
replies.text: @samgreen5517 I know it's like two months later but whatever. My interpretation of that is that it's a comment on the plight of the masses in mediaeval Germany. This period, together with the early modern period (up until ca. the Thirty Year's War, which is thought of as a kind of "breaking point" in German history), is often taught from a very elitist perspective where we learn a lot about the respective Holy Roman Emperors, their struggles with the Pope, etc. but relatively little about the daily life of the peasants and craftsmen who made that stuff possible. So my personal suspicion is that the red box represents the people living under the thumb of local princes, counts etc as well as the Church, who would keep them quiet for their own benefit and demand money to forgive their sins (one of the commonly mentioned reasons why people like Luther broke with the Catholic Church) as well as have major worldly holdings in mediaeval Germany. There were frequent uprisings by peasants in the early modern period as well, which were often analysed as early revolutionaries by left-wing thinkers; they were mostly just chaotic, anarchic revolts but could often be very bloody. The people in the box are the ordinary people upholding and enabling the power of the Church to "feast" on Germania; although they don't do so by choice (hence the box). The red light probably mostly is there to enhance the atmosphere of panic and craziness, although it may also symbolise the blood that has been shed in peasant revolts and executions, as well as draw a line to the communist interpretations of these events.

@UlitheUnruly I'm aware of that.

I'm also aware of the fact that the intention of the original lyrics back when they were originally written was yet another one:

At that time, "Germany" as we know it today consisted of a plethora of different kingdoms, principalities and other territories, and many people didn't view themselves as "Germans" but as "Saxons", "Prussians", "Bavarians", "Franks", "Frisians", "Westphalians" etc.

The anthem in its original form was intended to rally the people behind the idea of a united German nation, where everyone would view themselves as "Germans" first and foremost. Thus, "Germany, Germany above everything" was originally supposed to mean that the idea of a German nation should take priority over scattered regionalism.

The Nazis (among others) interpreted the lyrics differently, and thus changed the meaning for the worse.

Rammstein's version is rephrased to make that interpretation even more blatant... while being put in a new context that gives it yet ANOTHER new meaning.

replies.author: @Goldfire-tt3dv
replies.text:
@joanlynch5271 No, that's not the meaning. I'm German, and I've watched several analyses of this video. The point they're making is that you cannot separate the good parts of Germany's history from the bad parts. Both are forever part of our legacy.

It's not how critics make them feel, it's how they themselves feel on the inside. They can never unconditionally love their own country because of all the blood in our past.

The point of the song and the video is that it's important to remember it all, the good and bad stuff, instead of trying to brush aside the bad stuff and only focus on the good stuff.

Yes, our ancestors achieved a lot of things, but they also committed some horrible atrocities. Both are equally true. Germany is neither completely good nor completely bad.

Ultimately, the point of the song is a rejection of blind nationalism because that's always based on a rose-tinted view of any given country's history.

replies.text:
They have a twisted version of events surrounding the Second World War forgetting that the RAF carpet bombed Dresden and Florence killing innocent civilians.  Every VE Day on May 8th it's the same now.  The UK never used to mark that day and then in 2020 it replaced the May Day bank holiday with one the following weekend with 'socially distanced' drunken street parties. 

May Day is based on Beltane and then became International Workers' Day with trade union rallies and marches on the day or the following Saturday.  It was first made a bank holiday by a Labour Government in 1978.

The Nazis take much of their influences from the UK.  Winston Churchill was the first to use concentration camps.  Hitler Youth was inspired by photos of pupils at the top private boarding schools which are Rugby, Eton and Harrow.

replies.text:
I know it's been close to a year since the original comment, and us being fans I'm sure this isn't new knowledge. But I feel like adding some info.

But Rammstein not only IS NOT right wing, they straight up admitted they are left wing with the song ''Links 2 3 4''.

 It is a politically charged song, taking aim at early allegations of Nazism against the band by insinuating that they reside on the left side of the political spectrum instead.  They straight up called themselves Left-Wing and have consistently proven it.

replies.author: @ferrykeizer4911
replies.text:
@jager4508 Right, but they straight up called themselves left-wing. Literally. They didn't beat around the bush with it.

''Sie wollen mein Herz am rechten Fleck
Doch sehe ich dann nach unten weg
Da schl√§gt es links''

In English that's:
''they want my heart on the right place
but if i look down on me
then it beats left''

The song is about the subject of them being Left-Wing. That's what it's written about.

replies.author: @christianp.232
replies.text:
As a german I can just tell you, that the horrible 12 years in this country cut a wound so deep and so hard into the common soul of the people of Germany.
The first time I saw the video of 'Deutschland' was like --- somebody picked up the weird feelings most germans have to their country and brought it to life, you can listen and watch deeply into the soul of mine... and many others.
As a child of the 80's (getting 50 this week) I was confused my whole lifetime about what I could/should feel about Germany.
The History of this country is more than 1000 years back... but if you'd ask any german of the history, the past of Deutschland, 99% of them would be filled with consternation and think and tell you mainly about the Holocaust.
The modern Germany has nothing to do with the NS-Regime, but you feel guilty though...

The emotions to your country, worldwide, has something to do with patriotism and pride. As a german, you can only let these feelings come out at sport events :)
It's complicated and irritating. 
I think, we all could be proud of this nation, maybe it comes with age.
We should never forget the brutal and terrifying horror of the 'Third Reich' ! But we must somehow find a way, to let the good things Germany did, invented and so on be a bigger part of our souls. We also should celebrate, that Germany has become one of the most tolerant, open-minded and open-hearted societies in the world.

I'm thankful for my birth in a free, secure and open country. 
Don't forget, all people are part of the human family ! 

Best wishes to you from a little town nearly in the middle of good old Germany !  üá™üá∫üá™üá∫‚ù§üá©üá™üá©üá™‚ù§üá∑üá∫üá∑üá∫‚ù§üá∫üá¶üá∫üá¶‚ù§üá∫üá≥üá∫üá≥‚ù§üè≥‚Äçüåàüè≥‚Äçüåà‚ù§üïäüïä‚ù§‚òÆ‚òÆ‚ù§

A nazi is a particular kind of fascist, differing from other flavours in how the new class distinctions are to be drawn. Specifically they're white supremacists and anti-semites.


I don't think Jared Taylor is a nazi, since he's not particularly anti-semitic. He's most certainly a fascist, though.


I have no headcount of how many nazis there are in the US, Europe or worldwide. Enough, apparently that they can openly congregate, chant Blut und Boden and wave the nazi flag.


ISIS fighters aren't nazis. Their fascism is of a theological nature (that is, class distinction is based on religious and only remotely ethnic grounds).


Regarding Trump supporters, that's an odd question. Certainly most of them aren't nazis, I would hope. The aforementioned kind chanting nazi slogans and waving nazi flags probably are. Ironically, the Trump administration isn't really compatible with Nazism, since the racial currents are a bit of a fluke and motivations are nearly entirely economic. Trump doesn't have any issue employing illegal immigrants after all. The rhetoric is purely aimed at voters, not due to personal or administrative conviction.


In regards to a definition of fascism, refer to Umberto Eco's Ur-Fascism or The 14 characteristics of Fascism by Lawrence Britt for a cursory glance. Again, not all fascists are nazis, but all nazis are fascist. And the subject fills books, so you'll not just get "a definition" you can settle with.

author: @MrAbse2001
text:
As an Israeli Jew, I find this beautiful and not offensive at all. I have very controversial feelings towards Germany. 
I love this country, the language is beautiful so I learned it, the culture and food are great, and the people are really nice (at least today). However, as I said I am Jewish, moreover my parents are from Russia, I have everything to lead me to hate the country. Sometimes I feel guilty for loving it and being in Berlin got me in tears, thinking I am having good time where my great grandpa fought almost to death against the power of evil. I believe this song and its' video are representing the German patriotism, while criticizing their country and not being nationalist. They are afraid/ashamed to express their national feelings, and when they do we understand why. 
The moment I watched the video and I saw the lead singer dressed as a Jewish prisoner in a death camp saying "Deutschland √ºber allen" I was like "NOW THAT IS ART". This cynical expression of feelings towards your own country, made me feel like the Germans (as a nation and not as a state) did leave it in the past, and yet it is a part of who they are.
I don't want to make this comment to long, but there is much more to say.

I dont think being nationlist means you HAVE to think your country has no faults and is perfect. I dunno.. not trying to rip into you at all, just giving my thoughts, just been thinking about nationalism a lot lately with the U.S's current state haha

replies.author: @MarcFMusic
replies.text: Don't feel guilty for having a good time, where your grandpa fought almost to death... Feel blessed, that times have changed and you can actually have a good time there again! It's a privilege you should enjoy! We have to remember the past, so it won't happen again, but we also have to let it go. - Greetings from Germany!

replies.text:
I am not afraid or ashamed to express my national feelings, i do not want to express any feelings for the nation i live in. If being german and knowing german history does one thing for you, then to provide the insight into the nature of patriotism and nationalism as a mechanism of exclusion. Pride for a nation only is possible, when there are beings who are not part of what you're proud of there. There is nothing good for humans coming from being proud of something which some are not included into and you didn't do anything for in the first place as well.

Refusal of nationalism and "Nie Wieder!" ("Never Again!") is what my take from german history is - a lesson you can learn from it, even when not living here (and i wish you do learn from it).

replies.author: @michi6486
replies.text:
@midnattsol6207 I disagree with you to some degree. I am born in Germany 2 weeks after my parents migrated from ukraine. We are atheist but have jewish heritage. I do think it¬¥s fine to have national pride. I have such pride myself, but it becomes dificult if people do not understand the source for that pride. 
There are countries with history and then there is Germany. I think no country has been the fokal point of world history just like Germany. In it¬¥s darkest hours it showed the world just how dark and evil humanity can be but it also shows in it¬¥s history after WW2 how a nation can redefine itself. Germany today, maybe more than any major world leader (even USA after 2016) is maybe the quintessential democratic and liberal country. When in all western democracys the far right made a comeback, Germany manages to keep their own right wing at bay. When the world turned a blind eye to the migrants in 2015 germany was the one western country that reached out in big numbers. Germany has it¬¥s own problems and even though we keep our far right nationalist at bay, their presence is worrying, but we know our history, the good the bad and the ugly and take that and move forward with it in mind. We do not rewrite it or try to reframe it into something more pleasant to look at. I take pride in being part of a country that learns from its mistakes and tries to do better and actually does in many regards. Pride for prides sake is destructive, but pride taken from a development and using that pride to define your own values can be progressive.

replies.author: @doc0815martens
replies.text:
‚Äã@alexrenxa7700 well if you are proud of what your country has reached and you still ackknowledge its faults then you're a patriot which often is used in place of 'nationalist' but is the opposite in it's true meaning. A nationalist doesn't see any flaws or undesirable developments, on the contrary a patriot not only sees them but he tries to solve them. Also he does this in a way which serves everone in his country and not only those who follow his ideology while everyone other suffers from it.
Not everyone will share this opinion, but I do not care because the understanding of the terms 'nationalist' and 'patriot' is clearly defined.
A similar misunderstanding exists, for example, with the expressions 'to know' and 'believe to know / believe'. As soon as you believe, assume, suspect or consider something to be very likely, you automatically say that you just don't know.
But in general, 'believe' is far too often seen as a weakened form of 'knowing'. However, there are only two options, namely to know or not to know, which just includes 'believing' (I don't know, but I believe ...).

@alexrenxa7700 Almost every person in the late 19th century and early 20th century was a nationalist, from every country from every region. Everyone. Didnt matter if it was a Communist, Facist or Centrist Democrat. All looked at their country, loved it to death, but realized how things are now are bad and wrong and have to change.

Being a Communist in early 20th century doesnt mean destroying, hating your nation, but reshaping and rebuilding it from a old to new, better form. And thats what made Nationalists, Nationalists and why Nationalist movements spread Europe-wide in such a short time. Because everyone loved their culture and regions, they had different views on how to run said beloved country. That was is so different from todays politics. Back then they all believed in their great country that was just currently under wrong management and some wanted Revolutions, some wanted moderate change and some wanted to return to old teachings. But they were all united in the Love and Patriotism for their country. They all accepted the good and bad of their past, pretty much. Not everyone ofcourse. There will always be nutjobs only seeing great and good, not acknowledging the bad.

author: @jademoon7938
text: I've watched this video a few times, and I never once got the impression they were being exploitative or insensitive or anything like that. There's no disrespect. They're talking about their relationship with their homeland, a mix of pride and shame, love and hate, joy and pain. There are things to hold Germany up for, and things they should hang their heads for. Same as any country, though Germany has had a rocky road for one of the leading modern economies of today. How could they just leave out the Nazis? That would've seemed.. Like they were trying to pretend it didn't happen. It did. And they are ashamed of it. That's why they made themselves the victims. They sympathize. I just don't get the criticism. It's a mini movie of Germany's history. Can't just cut out the parts people would rather not think about. That would be wrong. I think it's beautiful and sad and it was moving. I love it. Rammstein has always been pushing the boundaries. I don't think this is one of those times. They're expressing their mixed feelings about their heritage in art. That's it.

replies.text:
This comment is well written but unfortunately is totally ignorant of the reality in Germany. Germany hasn't (and has never) forgotten its Nazi history. It is taught in schools. A visit to a concentration camp is in most parts of Germany part of the curriculum. There are memorials to the victims of the holocaust all over Germany (most prominently the one in Berlin).
There are stumbling stones marking the houses where Jews have lived before they were murdered. The German government feels a responsibility for the atrocities to this day and made clear that it wouldn't move its position of unquestioning support for Israel.

Germans have a hard time with just being proud of their country patriotism always has the reek of nationalism following it.
The ambivalence Rammstein describes of wanting to hate and love Germany is not new. 
The german satirist Jan B√∂hmermann made a song a few years before where he praises Germany and at the same time declares himselft to be proud not to be proud[to be german] ( youtube link: /watch?v=HMQkV5cTuoY )

replies.text:
Lord Farquaad TLDR: The USA became a superpower because they won WW2.

If the II. World War hadn't resulted in a defeat of Germany, the Marshall Plan wouldn't have existed. The Marshall Plan (and the US military presence) greatly increased US influence in western Europe. I guess not many Germans would speak English if the war had ended in a Stalemate. (I don't want to imagine what would have happened if Hitler had won.)


Whether that US influence is a good or a bad thing depends on your point of view. I think it's a pretty good outcome, if you compare the current peace and harmony with Europe's history. Chilling it under the extended sphere of influence of the US imperium is nice. (But their freedom treatment for those who don't want to isn't.)


Don't know whether Francisco Serra is really thinking about this, or just blurting out twisted ideas. Likely the latter, but I'm bored and need to waste some time :)

author: @mariamelnitskaya4493
text:
As a Russian/Belgian national I find this song extremely relatable and the lyrics works 100% accurate for both my national identities, if I replace Deutschland with Russland or Belgien. These are exactly the questions we're asking ourselves: who are we? is it possible to love our country after all the horrific things done? are we able to redeem ourselves? does this country have to exist at all? or we're too different to live together? or the existence of this state only brings misery and the world would be better off without it? 
And HUGE respect to Germans for asking these questions out loud and being brutally honest about their history. Thank you for giving a voice to my own feelings

replies.text: ‚Äã@MushroomCloudConfetti You might be surprised to hear that a lot of us Americans are not very patriotic. The American patriot stereotype only accounts for about half of the nation, mostly on the politically right side. You'll occasionally hear a pundit on the right warning of globalization. The politically left side is more prone to be critical of the country, feeling greater guilt for its failures and wanting to learn from other cultures. This is a very broad generalization, though. The country is so big and the culture so self-absorbed that many Americans on both sides of the political spectrum are unconcerned with the rest of the world and almost oblivious to it. The other countries of the world rarely have any noticeable influence on the average US citizen's life since our big corporations produce almost everything we see, so it's easy to feel like the rest of the world is irrelevant. I married an immigrant partly because he has an outsider's view of the US, providing me a lot of much-needed perspective that I probably wouldn't have gotten from another American.

replies.text: Patriotism and nationalism different concepts, although their opponents like to say they're both the same (and both relate to supporting the state). Nationalism is an emphasis on the unity of a people and/or greater need for self determination for a people (regardless of how the people is constructed). I agree with you. I am seeing this more and more here in Virginia. They are tearing down the statues of Confederate generals all over here and Maryland. They think that by removing the statues they are removing the negative feelings from that time period. Sadly, I believe that it is only going to cause more problems. Unlike Germany, it seems that people want to forget our painful past by erasing it. This is not what will happen. What people don't understand is that I have friends who had family members still alive who had been slaves when they were born in the 1970s. So the truth is slavery isn't that far away from current times. Yes, it was a very dark time in our countries history but we shouldn't forget it just because it is ugly. The way blacks were treated back then should never happen again. The only way to do this is by not forgetting our past. 

We are living through some very dark and uncertain times right now. We are currently dealing with the pandemic, outrage over blatant racism, police brutality, and an uncertain economic environment. I believe like many we are scared. People all over the world are feeling this as well. I pray that we as a people can be united and hopefully learn from this pandemic. 

As for the song it is wonderful, scare, and sad all at the same time. I can see that they are showing the world their country including all the ugly bits that most others would want to hide from the rest of the world. It takes a strong person to be able to look inward and see the worst parts of themselves. I believe they are doing this for Germany. 

I hope that you understand how I related this song to the current events here in my home state of Virginia, USA.

author: @MysticMindAnalysis
text:
Personally, I find any textual analysis of the lyrics make it pretty clear what this song is about. Rammstein want to love their country and embrace their national identity as Germans, but the country has gone down so many different dark roads that they have a largely love/hate relationship with Germany.


The concentration camps scene in particular shows the band members as the victims, rather than the perpetrators, and the camera's focus on Till singing as one of said victims illustrates who they're sympathising with.


Not to mention the end of the second verse being "Deutschland, Deutschland, Uber Allen/Germany, Germany Above All" (please pardon my terrible spelling) is delivered by a concentration camp inmate, turning back to the camera. This to me is a clear display of irony, openly mocking the fascist use of German Nationalism to kill religious and ethnic minorities within such a supposedly amazing nation.

replies.author: @elyjah6380
replies.text: Well put, managed to verbalise my thoughts exactly.

replies.author: @combine314
replies.text: I don't think it's really a display of irony. Till saying "Germany above all" as an inmate, even more as a Jew inmate, shows that those people from the concentration camp were actually as German as those executing them and who also saw Germany above all (things - I would say), in the sense of wanting a prosperous future for the nation and having the same love for their country. The irony being in that the Nazis were not killing enemies from another nation, but in fact they were killing their own people, their own fellow Germans. At least that's how I see it.

author: @luccorvus
text: I am a Dane whose German great grandfather was ripped away from his wife and son and forced to fight for the German side in WW2, just because he had German citizenship, despite living in Denmark. He was taken as a prisoner of war by the Americans and sent to the States until the war ended, which ultimately saved him. I felt many feelings watching the Rammstein video, but I never got the vibe that they in any way were romanticizing the nazies, quite the opposite. This video actually made me feel more connected to my German roots and I was so happy to see them cast such a beautiful woman to portray a wonderful country with such a long and complicated history.

replies.text: There is taboo as well as bad-boy cachet surrounding Germany's history. Can be distracting; I definitely sympathize.

replies.author: @Yutani_Crayven
replies.text:
I think German history is especially interesting because the "country" was such a massive ‚Ä¶ clusterfuck (for a lack of a better word) before unification under Bismarck in 1871. It was the last European country to come together as a nation state, in that sense. Everyone else got their shit sorted way sooner. The UK even got the prize for spearheading democracy.
Fun fact, German founding/unification at that time was also a major reason why all the other great powers were itching for a fight. France especially feared a strong German neighbour. And Germany, in its own right, feared losing out on overseas colonies.
Another fun fact ‚Äì at its founding and before WW1, Germany had a larger economy than the US. That looks much different now after everyone in Europe was fighting for so long while Americans pretty much got to sit it out and develop freely. So, now they're far at the top.
"Wer hoch steigt der wird tief fallen."

replies.author: @erikengheim1106
replies.text:
It is an extremely interesting country from a historical perspective as it has been the center of all modern European history. I am Norwegian but I really wish there was a better coverage of Germany in school. That there was more movies and such. I feel I know a lot about the US and the UK because of media, but very little about Germany which has had such profound influence on so many things.

Like I walk around in Oslo, Norway where I live in the beautiful old neighborhoods from the 1800s and it is only in the last few years I came to learn that the style was all influenced from Germany. That they bought whole building sections from Germany. When visiting Germany I see how so much in Scandinavia has this German influence and connection we never even hear about.

Berlin is very fascinating to visit I think, because you see the legacy of WWII as well as the cold war and the divided city. This city encapsulates the troubles Europe has gone through like few other cities.

replies.author: @meganoob12
replies.text:
the thing about German history, that makes it so interesting and inportant is, the geografical location of Germany.
In the center and the heart of Euroope lays a land devided into hundreds of small duchies and counties for hundreds of years, yet boasting the largest population in western europe and the potential of being the biggest economic power.
Why did Germany go through so many world changing events in it's history? Well because it was a sumbering super power for so long. The only thing that stood in the way of becoming a world leading power were the Germans themselves. It was also situated between the super powers of France, Britain, Austria and Russia, creating a balance of power for hundreds of years, until Germany united and suddenly became a superpower in itself.

author: @danielevanni6622
text:
Thank you so much for this!! As someone who learned German as a foreign language in high school, Rammstein were pivotal in keeping my interest in German culture and literature alive, as all of their songs have a plethora of more or less cryptic references to Goethe (in "Dalai Lama"), Feuerbach, (in "Mein Teil"),  Brecht (in "Haifisch") and so on. 

Probably wouldn't have had the same drive to learn and understand the language without them. I love how they create this double layer for the audience  - a "superficial" layer of interpretation that is just gory, shocking and weird, and a "deeper" one that is dense with poetry and commentary and kind of hidden behind a linguistic/cultural barrier. 

I sincerely believe Rammstein actually intended to spark a controversy. They knew some people would have taken the imagery at face value without making an intepretive effort. It's almost as if the shocking imagery was meant to cause a "Verfremdungseffekt" and force the audience to think deeper.

Cheers from Italy, a country which hasn't problematized its past nearly as much as Germany did, unfortunately.

replies.author: @skullarmi
replies.text: Coming from England, I completely understand that feeling of an over-glamourised or "glossed over" history. It's an embarassment of our countries inability to reconcile with our past.

author: @ProfDrLaeradr
text:
They also use the first verse of the german national hymn in a critical way and make it a parody of itself:

"Wer hoch steigt, der wird tief fallen
Deutschland, Deutschland √ºber allen."


"Whoever climbs high, will fall deep
Germany, Germany above all"

replies.author: @Quintinohthree
replies.text: It's important to note that by changing "alles" to "allen" the meaning of "all" changes from "all things" to "all people". I'll leave the analysis of that to the reader because I can read too much in to this to think of any succinct analysis.

replies.author: @Lightsellful
replies.text: It's incredibly pedantic but: the current german national anthem only has one verse, which is the third of the Deutschlandlied.

replies.author: @Milkymalk
replies.text:
What is parodied is neither the first nor ANY verse of the national anthem. The national anthem consists of exactly one verse which is the third verse of the song from which the first verse is being parodied, the "Lied der Deutschen".
It is important to understand what "Deutschland, Deutschland √ºber alles" / "Germany, Germany above all" in the lyrics of that song means in the historical context. When the song was written, there was no single German state, but German states, connected by their language, which were all but unified. The Holy Roman Empire had just crumbled under Napoleon's conquests. The lyrics of the song call for the German states to cease their petty quarrels and unify as a single nation for all German people. They should put the still-to-be-made German state "above all" other agendas. It is not, and never was, intended to mean to put Germany above all other nations.

replies.author: @Lightsellful
replies.text: @Milkymalk it certainly was used to mean that Germany is above the rest by the Nazis and earlier. Even with Hoffmanns contemporaries there was critisism of this line. This Problem is just pretty inherent, especially after the creation of Germany.

replies.author: @Milkymalk
replies.text: @Lightsellful The Nazis took a lot of stuff and perverted its meaning to their ends, as well as people not understanding where the lyrics came from and what they were meant to say. Doesn't mean it actually means that.

replies.author: @Lightsellful
replies.text:
@Milkymalk Ofcourse. But as it is, meaning isnt sth anyone can define and Copyright. The "missuse" of the line is much closer to the literal meaning of it. Compare that to the indirect, context-dependent original meaning, which even lost its direct reference after '71.
It's pretty much the same with the following geographical lines. Also compare with the history of the term "Reichskristallnacht".

replies.text: Milkymalk the issue with the idea that anything can ‚Äúactually‚Äù mean anything. It means what it‚Äôs used to mean.

replies.text: @sinomirneja771 Actually the dogs she gives birth to are Leonbergers, a German breed of dogs that were nearly extinct twice, with only 5 survivors after WWI and only 8 survivors after WWII. In both wars they were used to pull ammo carts. So I would say this symbolizes the "rebirth" of Germany after its two most violent periods. The video and music obviously deal with Germany's violent history and the repercussions of this violence today in German psyche. replies.author: @TheHeavyshadow
replies.text:
It has been some time since my history-lessons in high-school but I'm certain that was more than just lexical splitting of hairs. 
IIRC a "German Kaiser" would have simply meant a Kaiser who is of German nationality while "Kaiser of Germany" would have meant that now every territory that was under the reign of the Kaiser would be considered a part of Germany. The latter was quite the statement and preferred by a lot of political/military higher-ups in Germany, while of course not so much by other states. 
In the end they settled on something neutral during the proclamation to sidestep the issue, calling him "Majesty" or something like that.


But again: A pinch of salt is suggested with my recapture, it's been a hot minute since I last dealt with that topic.

author: @loltwest9423
text:
The lyrics "I want to love you but also condemn you" hit pretty hard for me. I personally feel like it perfectly encapsulates the message of the song. They can't forget the horrible atrocities of their past, and neither will they let it go, no matter how much they want to love their country and its achievements.

The craziest bit for me personally is the V2 rockets bit. From the American perspective and knowing what those rockets eventually lead to, it's a crazy contrast seeing this technological advancement achieved during the time period of such insane atrocity.

The whole message I got was that to nature of the German identity is one of wanting to love a country but grappling with its many and horrific atrocities.

All I'm gonna say is, watching the development of modern Germany and seeing where you and the other Germans go from here will be fascinating.




(Also you validated my theory that they chose a black woman to represent the spirit of Germania to avoid or spit in the face of accusations of being "far-right.")

replies.author: @Regis1995
replies.text: Portraying Germania as female is not "immense" at all. She has been protrayed as female since 1848 and is a traditionally female character. You also seem to imply that the term "fatherland" is somehow bad... whether a language features "fatherland" or "motherland" is defined by a long linguistic history, not by their views on men and women. Germanic languages evolved to use fatherland (vaterland, vaderland, etc. is a theme in Germanic languages), some others have motherland like the Slavic languages, etc. It has no meaning and also stems from a time before we (Germanic peoples, that is) had a strict Christian patriarchy installed and had a more egalitarian view of women in pagan times (note: they weren't perfect societies of course, but they were nowhere near as patriarchal as the later Christian societies and women were a lot more prominent in the religion, culture and they were more flexible when it came to traditional roles). You can compare this to the outrage I sometimes see over the term "mankind" in English, even though linguistically mankind doesn't refer to men at all. Linguistically, man and woman started out as wereman and woman, with man referring to both. Wereman evolved to drop the "were", but mankind stayed the same. To compare, in Germanic languages it's man/frau/mensch, man/vrouw/mens etc. etc., you see the three distinct terms. More often than not, linguistics is just linguistics with no bad intentions behind them.

replies.author: @hedgehog3180
replies.text:
>  This is different to most other cultures that call them the motherland (or some other femenine variation).


This is a bit more complex. In Northern European countries the term fatherland is very common and it's used in the Nordics as well so it's not like most of the world uses motherland. In Danish it's the fatherland but the language is the mother's tongue so there is a historical duality there. And I think in this case given that personifications of countries often were women and specifically Germania was a woman this isn't really weird. Many other countries had similar personifications like Columbia for the US, and Britannia for the UK. The difference just is that those two haven't really survived and Uncle Sam has become the personification of the US instead with Mother Russia sorta being the only one to stick around. And of course quite a few countries never really had a personification in that sense.


Good catch on the thing with the eye and scaring though, that's actually genuinely super clever and I hadn't thought about that myself.

The seven core tenets of nationalism:

1. If an area was ours for 500 years and yours for 50 years, it should belong to us ‚Äì you are merely occupiers.

2. If an area was yours for 500 years and ours for 50 years, it should belong to us ‚Äì borders must not be changed.

3. If an area belonged to us 500 years ago but never since then, it should belong to us ‚Äì it is the cradle of our nation.

4. If a majority of our people live there, it must belong to us ‚Äì they must enjoy the right of self-determination.

5. If a minority of our people live there, it must belong to us ‚Äì they must be protected against your oppression.

6. All of the above rules apply to us, but not to you.

7. Our dream of greatness is historical necessity, yours is fascism.

replies.author: @Quotenwagnerianer
replies.text:
It's also a clever word play on the misinterpretation of the original national anthems lyrics by the right wing nationalists. 
"Deutschland, Deutschland √ºber alles, √ºber alles in der Welt" does not mean that Germany towers above everything else in the world. It means that it is more close to the heart to a German than everything else in the world.
By changing it to "Deutschland, Deutschland √ºber allen" it actually becomes what the Nazis thought  it meant, that Germany is better than everything else in the world and that it should rule over the world.

replies.author: @RustyDust101
replies.text:
@Quotenwagnerianer The Germans of the time when the "Lied der Deutschen" was composed had seen again and again that their tiny nation-states had absolutely no bloody chance at defending against larger, stronger nation's armies, such as at that time most recently, the French. Every other nation-state in Europe held much more political and military power compared to almost any of the tiny nation states of the Holy Roman Empire of Germanic Nations, possibly with the exception of Austria-Hungary, Bavaria, and Prussia. Any neighbor who wanted to could easily take chunks out of the HRE at any time because there was no unified army to defend the states; only the small local armed forces of the local nobles.
 The "Deutschland, Deutschland √ºber alles" actually refers to the idea  from the 1848 "Lied der Deutschen" / "Song of the Germans" of a whole, unified Germany as opposed to seeing yourself as a Badenser, Swabian, Bavarian, Frankonian, Hannoveranian, Bremerian, Schleswiger, Holsteiner, Rhinelander, Prussian, Silesian, Pommeraninan, yada-yada-yada, you get the drift. The HRE's previous tiny noble fiefdoms looked across their borders and saw strong, powerful nation states pop up everywhere around them, and were very afraid for their saftey. The only solution they saw to prevent themselves from being gobbled up in nice bite-sized chunks was to become part of a unified whole nation-state that would defend ALL of its member states.
Therefore you should not think as a member of one of the dozens, if not hundreds of small, independent tiny baronies, duchies, earldoms, and micro-kingdoms that made up the 'Holy Roman Empire of Germanic Nations', but rather as a person of a unified nation of Germany. The idea of a whole, unified Germany should thus actually be translated much more as "Germany before the sub-set of states". That was the basic drive of the time: to finally unify Germany so it might have a chance to defend itsself against its many times more powerful neighbors. Agreed, it does not have the same ring or fluidity to it. That's what cramming such a line into a song does for the context, damn it.


So the "Deutschland √ºber allen" is much more the Nazi intent. Obviously (hopefully, I got it immediately) this version means the superiority complex the Nazis had. As such it was, again, obviously a very bitterly-cynical parody of the original lyrics.

author: @arbysmakesfries5787
text:
There's another level of analysis you're missing about the song "Radio" beyond a simple portrayal of the DDR's state censorship and the ray of hope provided by Western radio broadcasts. The Slovenian Marxist philosopher Slavoj ≈Ωi≈æek who is very close to Rammstein's ideological orbit (essentially the house intellectual of the Neue Slowenische Kunst art collective whose musical wing, the band Laibach, is possibly Rammstein's single most important musical and aesthetic influence) has claimed that illicit availability of Western media was actually a helpful safety valve for the old Eastern Bloc regimes in maintaining control for as long as they did, since it directed people's political hopes toward the fantasy of escaping to a utopian society somewhere else, and thereby helped divert their political hopes from the possibility of tangibly changing the society they actually lived in. (Ironically, this also strongly resembles the classic Marxist critique of religion: by goading people into believing that they'll get "pie in the sky when they die" in Heaven, the ruling elite tries to dilute the political potency of people's demands for a better life here and now on Earth.)


Signs of this critique are clear in at least a few places in the music video for the song "Radio". First you have what seems to be a popular street uprising, complete with visual allusions to the iconic "Liberty Leading the People" figure from the French Revolution, but then it turns out to just be a consumerist mob descending on an electronics store to loot a bunch of radios; ≈Ωi≈æek himself has talked at length about the role of consumerist looting frenzies as a diversion from more substantive political protest, a type of scene also depicted more explicitly and at greater length by the Bosnian leftist band Dubioza Kolektiv in their video for the song "Himna Generacije" ("Hymn for a Generation"). Then you have the scene where East German riot police show up at the recording studio to break up the band's radio broadcast, but it turns out they're swinging their riot clubs through holograms of the band members, and soon they launch into a choreographed dance routine on the outro chorus; one could interpret this as Western music finally capturing the hearts and minds of even the regime's own hired thugs, but a deeper interpretation is that the regime itself is tolerating and tacitly endorsing the broadcast, and they're only superficially play-acting to trick people into thinking they want to shut it down.


The coup de gr√¢ce though is in the last few seconds, where the video cuts from black-and-white to color and the band is shown leaving the studio: the banners flying outside the studio are colored in vintage communist red-and-yellow, but instead of a hammer and sickle, the logo on the banners is the star circle of the present-day EU flag. To me the message here is that on a deeper level, the band isn't really singing about the DDR at all, and much like ≈Ωi≈æek often does in his philosophical lectures, they're using the more obvious (especially in hindsight) ideological repression of the Eastern Bloc period as an analogy to help understand the less obvious (especially in the moment) ideological repression of the modern capitalist West. So maybe the song is actually trying to tell us that we shouldn't think of ourselves as so much less ideologically restricted than those poor communist Easterners tuning their radios to Western media as a form of escapism, because maybe our computers and smartphones tuned to social media or Netflix or YouTube are playing the same escapist safety-valve role for us right now today.

author: @haidouk872
text:
I'm not that familiar with Rammenstei, but I know that, even outside of this song, Germans in general tend to be honest with their history and face it very straightforwardly (not all, but still). And I kinda respect and admire that.

As a French, I wish I could say the same about my country, but unfortunately, we have a much more complicated relationship with the dark sides of our past. Whenever we look at our history, our eyes get distracted away by the "radiant light" of glorious historical characters and events with all the national myth built around them. And thus, all the bad stuff we did ends up remaining invisible, in the shadow of the more glorious sides. 
And whenever you try to talk about the crimes our country did, or whenever to try to bring some nuance to a character important in the national myth, you have hordes of bitter french jumping at your throat, accusing you of all names. They will go on rant about how nowadays all the education and the public discussion is about teaching young french to hate their own country, and that we don't have to keep giving excuses forever. But the truth is that, because of those reactions from a big part of the population, the discussions on the topic are really touchy and always end up being manichean. 
Unlike Germany, we haven't been forced to face our history, because we were part of the "good guys" in WW2 and Cold War, so we were kinda protected by the "morally good" aura. But really, we are like UK, in the sense that our history is full of very dark moments that are still talked about, and that cause a lot uneasiness in the public discussion.
People will accuse you of not loving your country, but this is when I ask: how can you truly love your country if you haven't faced and accepted its sins before?

author: @daddyleon
text: *+Three Arrows* What about that "Germania" dies and is given a space burial, suggesting that the idea of Germany will die in the future anyway. And that all this nationalism was a weird and troubled concept to begin with. An outsider's fiction (Romans) in the first place; that was nevertheless adopted by the natives that didn't really seem to live up to it (the scene of Germans eating Germania during the middle ages), with sometimes being a uniting force (Germania in battle gear); with the notion of "Germania" being fully corrupted during WW2 and the DDR-time; and after being somewhat salvaged the RAF tries to tare it all up; but eventually...she dies when we reach space and earthbound nationality doesn't even register. To me this suggests something like: the only way we can finally be free of all the negativity it has, is once it just dies; because it can always be corrupted, always held hostage; it can change, but it's always a tool that's never just 'good'.

@gokumetrix80 Lol, you must be kidding. Iceland - with a population the size of a regional hub city - had its fair share of warfare (both raiding and being raided) and violent religious and political struggles. It's capitalised heavily on its strategic military location to get US support from WW2 on. For instance, it received the most per capita funds from the Marshall plan, despite having been neutral and largely untouched in WW2. It also used its importance to the US to force the UK fishing fleet to abandon its traditional fishing grounds. 
Incidentally, Iceland is one of the very few European countries that supported the US's invasion of Iraq (including sending forces).

author: @Pincer88
text:
Very good analysis and one I adhere to wholehartedly. 


I must say Rammstein's 'synopsis' of Germany's history  is admirably self-critical and is - at least in my eyes - not at all offensive. I really detest the reflex by some to protest against this depiction without even understanding (or trying to understand) what they see or what the message is. I know, this may sound very shallow with the recent events in Halle in mind, but everyone with a right mind can see that Rammstein's message is pretty simple: the old sentiments are never far away, beware. And as you rightfuly state: those sentiments were never and still are not unique to Germany. 
Being Dutch I have got to say, that there's no nation that I know of that has shown such devotion to dealing with the dark pages of its history. Most other nations still glorify their past, even when it consists of conquest, supression and exploitation (colonialism, anyone?). The way I perceive our German neighbours is with respect. Of course there are biggots in Germany like anywhere else. But the mainstay of German people are decent, polite ("h√∂fflich"), hard working, honest and sympathetic men and women. I hope that anyone who sees Rammstein's video would stay away from the reflex-like reaction and instead becomes interested in Germany, its rich culture, history and beautiful language (yes, of course, wenn not pronounciated like a Gestapo-officer). It saddens me to see that so many never have read (or heard about) Erich K√§stner, Hermann Hesse, Goethe, Lessing ("Nathan der Weise!!!") or Rilke. If the only way we can see Germany is through a lense of the 2nd Worldwar, we fail ourselves. So from the Netherlands: a heartfelt compliment both on this video, as on Rammstein and present day Germany. Zum Wohl.

author: @fiendishrabbit8259
text:
I'm continually somewhat disappointed by the incompleteness of various analyses of "Deutschland". This video discusses wether the video is controversial or not, which it kinda isn't, but a full analysis of what it actually tries to say isn't complete without an analysis of the fantasy and futuristic elements as well.

My overall analysis of the video would be that it's a critique of the continual use of the national image to serve various elites, a germania that's continually reinvented, resurrected, abused and held hostage, but where the common denominator is the violence against the people of germany (minorities, workers, individuals) and its collapse in violence. Then its history is re-analysed, re-invented, whitewashed and re-used. The wealthy men walking away from the zeppelin as it explodes, then walking ahead of Germania as dogs and then Germania giving birth to Leonberger puppies IMHO reinforces this Destruction, Reinvention, Whitewashing, Re-use storytelling, as does the continual use of red lasers which are omni-present but when functionally used they're used as scanners in some scenes, and destructive beams in others.

The use of a black actress (and german citizen) as Germania is both to distance itself from right-wing ideas of what germany is, but also due to aesthetics. Her very dark skin colour is used in combination with a Gold&Red or White&Red colourscheme, representing the Black/White/Red and Black/Gold/Red colourscheme of the german flag.

author: @radunMARSHAL
text: The battle at Teutoburg forest and the story of Armenius doesn't actually go like that. He was a Germanic guy educated and brought up in Rome as a hostage, but he was also a Roman officer commanding the Germanic auxiliaries in Germania Magna. Even though Germania Magna was still not a pacified and integrated province, it was roaming with Roman soldiers and the legions annihilated at Teutoburg forest were actually moving from their summer camp near the river Wesser to their winter camp closer to the river Rhine where Roman influence was much stronger and they were much better protected from attack by the local unsubjugated tribes. So, while Varus, the commander of the legions soon to be annihilated was travelling with his forces toward West, his trusted subcommander, scout and guide Armenius with his Germanic forces was present and riding with the rest of the Roman force. Due to his influence and trust with Varus, he was able to convince him in the existence of a rebellion in the region that required Varus's immediate response, convincing Varus to take the quickest possible rout through territories unfamiliar to Varus and the Romans. He was able to do that due to Varus holding a lot of trust in his fellow subcommander and, even though he realized that passing through unfamiliar forested terrain was dangerous for him and his forces, he held complete trust in Armenius and his Germanic cavalry guiding them through and watching over their flanks. That's how Varus and his legions walked into an ambush set by Armenius who simply disappeared along with his forces when the ambush sprang. In the end, Armenius was murdered by his fellow Germans due to behaving like he was taught in Rome, like their ruler and not one of the tribal chiefs.

author: @Daneelro
text:
A historical note on the part from 10:07: I disagree with the mainstream notion that hyperinflation was the key economic shock that created the basis for the rise of Nazism. This overplays the actual importance of hyperinflation and erases another, bigger economic shock from German history.

Hyperinflation did not hit all classes equally: it hit first and foremost those with savings, that is, the upper classes and the middle class. Of course, the voters of Adenauer's CDU remembered this the most, but they weren't the key demographic for the rise of Nazism. Indeed in spite of the violent birth of the Weimar Republic, hyperinflation wasn't followed by a wave of violence, and extremist parties did not rise for several years after it.

However, there was an economic shock which directly preceded/was contemporaneous with the rise of the Nazis and which impacted the different classes quite differently. It was the austerity policies implemented by the minority government of Heinrich Br√ºning, which governed with outside support from the Social Democrats from March 1930. This austerity regime was a reaction to runaway budget deficits caused by both the onset of Depression in the US (which was a key trading partner) and reinforced demands for speedy war reparations from European countries. Based on entirely wrong conservative fiscal dogma (which dominates Germany to this day and was key to the crushing of Greece during the Euro crisis), this austerity regime failed to correct the fiscal situation, while making millions of workers jobless. Those workers were in a much more precarious situation than those hit by hyperinflation a few years earlier. As a consequence, many joined militias, and even more abandoned their traditional parties in the next elections, especially the Social Democrats (who, sadly, chose to only remember the subplot of this story that was the Communist vs Social Democrat conflict, instead of recognising their then leaders' error in judgement, and placing the main blame squarely on the centre-right).

replies.author: @Daneelro
replies.text:
Since Three Arrows actually credits, in part, the austerity measures with the improvement of the financial situation after the Nazi takeover (when speaking about full employment), I should add my disagreement on that, too. 

First, a bit more on why austerity was a failure. Prior to the 1929 crash, Germany could only service its WWI debts thanks to its trade surplus with the US. When Depression hit the US, for Germany, that meant a major drop in exports to the US, thus servicing the debt from taxes on economic production already became mathematically impossible. (The alternatives would have been to sell parts of the national wealth or heavily tax private wealth.) The Br√ºning government, due to their belief that the finances of a national economy work just like those of a household, thought saving on government expenses will do the trick. But a national economy is different from a household because the expenses of one economic player are the income of another economic player within the national economy. In this instance, the private economy was hit by the loss of government orders, the income loss of fired workers and government employees translated into a reduced demand for consumer goods and thus an even stronger shrinking of economic activity, and the recession resulted in reduced tax income for the government, keeping the deficit from closing.

The Nazis ended this death spiral by ending the payment of WWI debt. Of course, this wasn't a temporary suspension motivated by financial rationality, but a permanent refusal motivated by a nationalistic denial of war responsibility and an underlying aim to start re-armament, something the debt payments were supposed to prevent. (Arguably, Germany could have serviced its debts again after the onset of the New Deal in the US.)

text: I'm an American that has loved Rammstein for about two decades, seen them live three times and am writing this from Berlin where I'm currently living and I can tell you that Rammstein are in no way Nazis üòÖ I can also tell you that Germany as a whole is obsessed, in a good way, with their history. Everywhere you go in Berlin there are reminders and memorials. This video makes perfect sense to me. The only thing that I would disagree with is calling it lazy marketing. Rammstein is all about playing with people's perception of reality and preconceived notions in order to turn them on their head and get people talking. The conclusions that people jump to in turn say a lot more about the observer than the artist.
